nodes.label: Vygotsky
nodes.notes: Considered by most to be originator of **sociocultural theory** and it's many sub-branches / related names.

nodes.label: Activity Systems / Triangle
nodes.notes:
The idea that collective activity is the ideal unit of analysis for understanding human behavior / learning. The triangle is the common representation of this. Here is a sample from Danish et al., 2011: 
 
![Sample Activity Triangle](http://joshuadanish.com/imgs/triangle.png)

See Engeström's writing for details.

nodes.label: Vygotsky (1978)
nodes.info: Sociocultural, CHAT, W3, W4, W6, ZPD
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Vygotsky, L. S. (1978). Mind in society: the development of higher psychological processes. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.

nodes.label: Mediation
nodes.info: Sociocultural, CHAT, Activity Theory, W3, W5
nodes.notes: A central idea in CHAT. Danish (2014) summarized it as the process of being "between" two things and transforming their relationship.

nodes.label: US, 1978
nodes.notes:
This is much later than Vygotsky's contemporaries were read widely in the US due in large part to the cold war.

This is also a time when cognitive science is rising.

Etc.

nodes.label: Susan Jurow
nodes.notes: [www.colorado.edu/education/susan-jurow](https://www.colorado.edu/education/susan-jurow)

nodes.label: Kris Gutierréz
nodes.notes: https://gse.berkeley.edu/kris-d-gutiérrez

nodes.label: Michael Cole
nodes.notes: https://psychology.ucsd.edu/people/profiles/mcole.html

nodes.label: Cole (2013)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Cole, M. (2013). Prologue: Reading Vygotsky. In R. W. Rieber & D. K. Robinson (Eds.), The essential Vygotsky: Springer Science & Business Media.

nodes.label: Third Space
nodes.notes:
A social space where the official script and unofficial counter-script come together and support engagement and learning.

See: Gutierrez, K. D., Rymes, B., & Larson, J. (1995). Script, Counterscript, and Underlife in the Classroom: James Brown versus Brown v. Board of Education. Harvard Educational Review, 65(3), 445-471.

nodes.label: Jurow, Horn & Philip (2018)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Jurow, S., Horn, I. S., & Philip, T. M. (2018). Re-mediating knowledge infrastructures: a site for innovation in teacher education. Journal of Education for Teaching, 45(1), 82-96.

nodes.label: Wilson (accepted)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Wilson, N. C. (accepted). Examining the Impact of Systemic Tensions on Agency and Identity: The Multiple Positions of Reggie in Production-Centered, Technology-Mediated Activity.

nodes.label: _Notes_
nodes.notes:
This graph is intended to be:

* **collaborative** I hope that you all will add your ideas, edit things, and discuss.

* **evolving** I hope that this will continue to change over time as we explore.

* **emergent** This is intended to capture our key ideas at the moment, not to be systematic and all-encompassing. Thus I am adding nodes and edges as they appear relevant. If you think I missed one, feel free to add it! 

* **A note on "theory"**: In order to avoid a massive amount of uninformative cross-linking, I assume these ideas are all broadly sociocultural. Other sub-theoretical ideas or frameworks (including that one) that we might use to refer to them are then listed as "tags" so they are visible in the tables and filters.

nodes.label: Persistent Educational Inequities
nodes.notes:
The US (the context I am most familiar with) and the world continue to struggle with inequities in educational experiences (and many other life experiences) that are heavily correlated with race, gender, SES, ethnicity, and other factors.

**Note**: It would be easy to argue, of course, that this is the context of *all* of the work in this graph. However, we are using it to reference those papers that explicitly call it out.

nodes.label: Racism
nodes.notes: A definition is outside the scope of this course, though this is a powerful and harmful social construct / force addressed by many of our readings and hence is included for context.

nodes.label: _Disclaimer_
nodes.notes: **Disclaimer**: This network is not intended to capture objectively "true" relationships. Nor have I consulted with the authors. They might every well disagree with some of my characterizations. Rather, this is intended to capture our current collective thinking about the relationships that we see as relevant within our readings during this course.

nodes.label: Double Stimulation
nodes.notes:
Method developed by Vygotsky (1978), primarily in Ch 5. 

"The task facing the child in the experimental context is, as a rule, beyond his present capabilities and cannot be solved by existing skills. In such cases a neutral object is placed near the child, and frequently we are able to observe how the neutral stimulus is drawn into the situation and takes on the function of a sign."

nodes.label: Play
nodes.notes: Play is defined by Vygotstky (1978) as always consisting of an imaginary situation and a set of rules. This is a leading activity of childhood which promotes development. See the articles for more detail.

nodes.label: Learning
nodes.notes:
This gets defined in many ways subtly here, and existed long before each person who is developing it, but not all of our papers focus on learning so I wanted to call it out.

Note that Vygotsky (1978) indicates a very particular relationship to development in particular.

nodes.label: Zone of Proximal Development (ZPD)
nodes.notes: The difference between what a learner can do independently and what they can accomplish with assistance from a more capable other. Within the zone are those psychological functions that are maturing (as opposed to those that are "fossilized" or not yet within a learners' capability).

nodes.label: Development
nodes.notes: "We believe that child development is a complex dialectical process characterized by periodicity, unevenness in the development of different functions, metamorphosis or qualitative transformation of one form into another, intertwining of external and internal factors, and adaptive processes which overcome impediments that the child encounters." (Vygotsky, 1978).

nodes.label: Sign mediation
nodes.notes: See mediation.

nodes.label: Tool mediation
nodes.notes: See mediation more broadly.

nodes.label: Genetic Approach
nodes.notes: Vygotsky's (1978) approach which requires understanding the development of a process to understand its nature, not the final product.

nodes.label: Wertsch (2017)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Wertsch, J. V. (2017). Mediated action. In W. Bechtel & G. Graham (Eds.), A companion to cognitive science (pp. 518-525). MA, USA: Blackwell Publishing Ltd.

nodes.label: Kaptelinin (2015)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Kaptelinin, V. (2015). Designing mediation. Paper presented at the Proceedings of the European Conference on Cognitive Ergonomics 2015.

nodes.label: Jurow & Shea (2015)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Jurow, A. S., & Shea, M. (2015). Learning in Equity-Oriented Scale-Making Projects. Journal of the Learning Sciences, 24(2), 286-307. doi: 10.1080/10508406.2015.1004677

nodes.label: Danish (2014)
nodes.info: W5, CHAT, activity theory, mediation, design
nodes.notes:
**Citation**: Danish, J. A. (2014). Applying an Activity Theory Lens to Designing Instruction for Learning About the Structure, Behavior, and Function of a Honeybee System. Journal of the Learning Sciences, 23(2), 1-49. Retrieved from [doi](https://doi.org/10.1080/10508406.2013.856793)

More about [BeeSign](http://www.joshuadanish.com/projects/BeeSign.html).

nodes.label: Roth (2007)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Roth, W.-M. (2007). On Mediation: Toward a Cultural-Historical Understanding. Theory & Psychology, 17(5), 655-680. doi:10.1177/0959354307081622

nodes.label: Design
nodes.notes: Work that explores design.

nodes.label: Re-Mediation
nodes.notes: The idea of changing the mediational means, but continuing to support the same basic functional relationship. Not to be confused with the current notion of helping "catch someone up" when they are not performing well.

nodes.label: Joshua Danish
nodes.notes: www.joshuadanish.com

nodes.label: Chaiklin (2003)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Chaiklin, S. (2003). The Zone of Proximal Development in Vygotsky's Analysis of Learning and Instruction. In A. Kozulin, B. Gindis, V. S. Ageyev, & S. M. Miller (Eds.), Vygotsky's Educational Theory in Cultural Context. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

nodes.label: Smagorinsky (2018)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Smagorinsky, P. (2018). Deconflating the ZPD and instructional scaffolding: Retranslating and reconceiving the zone of proximal development as the zone of next development. Learning, Culture and Social Interaction, 16, 70-75. doi:10.1016/j.lcsi.2017.10.009

nodes.label: Leonardo (2015)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Leonardo, Z., & Manning, L. (2015). White historical activity theory: toward a critical understanding of white zones of proximal development. Race Ethnicity and Education, 20(1), 15-29.

nodes.label: Scaffolding
nodes.notes: NOT the same as the ZPD, but often referenced in discussions of the ZPD.

nodes.label: Wood, Bruner, and Ross (1976)
nodes.notes:
Often cited as the origin of the term Scaffolding.

The ZPD / Vygotsky are *not* mentioned.

nodes.label: Boblett (2012)
nodes.notes:
**Citation**: Boblett, N. (2012). Scaffolding: Defining the Metaphor. Teachers College, Columbia University Working Papers in TESOL & Applied Linguistics, 12(2), 1-16. 

This paper attempts to situate / explore the relationship / overlap between scaffolding and the ZPD.

nodes.label: Griffin & Cole (1984)
nodes.notes:
**Citation**: Griffin, P., & Cole, M. (1984). Current activity for the future: The Zo-ped. New Directions for Child Development, 23, 45-64. 

Lays out the idea of leading activities in greater clarity.

nodes.label: Leading Activity
nodes.notes: The major activity presumed to drive development for learners within a particular psychological age (not biological) within a given social context. See Griffin (1984) or Chaiklin (2003) for details.

nodes.label: Wertsch (1981)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Wertsch, J. V. (1981). The Concept of Activity in Soviet Psychology: An Introduction. In J. V. Wertsch (Ed.), The Concept of Activity in Soviet Psychology (pp. 3-36). Armonk, N.Y.: M.E. Sharpe.

nodes.label: Engeström (1990)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Engeström, Y. (1990). When is a tool?  Multiple meanings of artifacts in human activity. In Y. Engestrom (Ed.), Learning, working and imagining: twelve studies in activity theory (pp. 171-195). Helsinki: Orienta-Konsultit Oy.

nodes.label: Lee (2001)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Lee, C. D. (2001). Is October Brown Chinese? A cultural modeling activity system for underachieving students. American Educational Research Journal, 38(1), 97-97.

nodes.label: Gutiérrez (2002)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Gutiérrez, K. (2002). Studying Cultural Practices in Urban Learning Communities. Human Development, 45(4), 312-321.

nodes.label: Vélez-Agosto, et al (2017)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Vélez-Agosto, N. M., Soto-Crespo, J. G., Vizcarrondo-Oppenheimer, M., Vega-Molina, S., & García Coll, C. (2017). Bronfenbrenner’s bioecological theory revision: Moving culture from the macro into the micro. Perspectives on Psychological Science, 12(5), 900-910.

nodes.label: Culture
nodes.notes:
Definition from Gutiérrez (2002):

"Hence, while culture can be broadly understood as the patterns of beliefs, values, and practices that we both inherit and transform over time, individuals never share all of the culture of the group to which they belong."(p 314)

nodes.label: Esteban-Guitart, et al (2020)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Esteban-Guitart, M., Monreal-Bosch, P., Palma, M., & González-Ceballos, I. (2020). Sustaining Students’ Identities within the Context of Participatory Culture. Designing, Implementing and Evaluating an Interactive Learning Activity. Sustainability, 12(12). doi:10.3390/su12124870

nodes.label: Funds of Identity
nodes.notes: "In this sense, funds of identity are understood to comprise those people, spaces, things and activities which, for the learners, are the most important and most relevant, and which, ultimately, best define them" (Esteban-Guitart, et al, 2020, p 3)

nodes.label: Duncan & Tarulli (2003)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Duncan, R. M., & Tarulli, D. (2003). Play as the leading activity of the preschool period: Insights from Vygotsky, Leont'ev, and Bakhtin. Early Education & Development, 14(3), 271-292.

nodes.label: Perone & Göncü (2014)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Perone, A., & Göncü, A. (2014). Life-Span Pretend Play in Two Communities. Mind, Culture, and Activity, 21(3), 200-220.

nodes.label: Appropriation
nodes.notes: In CHAT theory, appropriation is meant to extend and clarify the notion of "internalization" by indicating that learners need both construct their own internal representation of a mediator, meaning that it is necessarily transformed, and that there is a distinction between mastery and seeing the value of doing something. When a psychological tool is appropriated, learners will use it and see the value in it, not just be able to reproduce it on command.

nodes.label: Engeström (2018)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Engeström, Y. (2018). Expansive learning: Towards an activity-theoretical reconceptualization. In Contemporary theories of learning (pp. 46-65): Routledge.

nodes.label: Postholm (2020)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Postholm, M. B. (2020). Premises and Promises for Expansive Learning in Teacher Education. Frontiers in Education, 5.

nodes.label: Rust (2020)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Rust, F. (2020). Expansive Learning Within a Teachers Community of Ongoing Learners (TCOOL). Frontiers in Education, 5.

nodes.label: Engeström (1991)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Engeström, Y. (1991). Non Scolae Sed Vitae Discimus: Toward Overcoming the Encapsulation of School Learning. Learning and Interaction, 1, 243-259.

nodes.label: Bal, Afacan & Cakir (2018)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Bal, A., Afacan, K., & Cakir, H. I. (2018). Culturally Responsive School Discipline: Implementing Learning Lab at a High School for Systemic Transformation. American Educational Research Journal, 55(5), 1007-1050.

nodes.label: Rajala & Sannino (2015)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Rajala, A., & Sannino, A. (2015). Students’ deviations from a learning task: An activity-theoretical analysis. International Journal of Educational Research, 70, 31-46.

nodes.label: Yamagata-Lynch & Haudenschild (2009)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Yamagata-Lynch, L. C., & Haudenschild, M. T. (2009). Using activity systems analysis to identify inner contradictions in teacher professional development☆. Teaching and Teacher Education, 25(3), 507-517.

nodes.label: Engestrom (1987)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Engeström, Y. Learning by Expanding: An Activity- Theoretical Approach to Developmental Research. Helsinki: Orienta-Konsultit Oy, 1987.

nodes.label: Cole (1996)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Cole, M. (1996). Cultural psychology. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press.

nodes.label: Danish et al (2020)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Danish, J. A., Enyedy, N., Saleh, A., & Humburg, M. (2020). Learning in embodied activity framework: a sociocultural framework for embodied cognition. International Journal of Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning, 15(1), 49-87.

nodes.label: Funds of Knowledge
nodes.notes:
For definitions see these cites from the Esteban-Guitart article we read:
* González, N.; Moll, L.; Amanti, C. Funds of Knowledge: Theorizing Practices in Households, Communities, and Classrooms; Lawrence Erlbaum Associates: Mahwah, NJ, USA, 2005; pp. 1–307. 22. 
* Moll, L. Vygotsky and Education; Routledge: New York, NY, USA, 2014. 23. 
* Moll, L. Elaborating funds of knowledge: Community-oriented practices in international contexts. Lit. Res. 2019, 67, 12–18.

nodes.label: Leont’ev
nodes.notes: Colleague / student of Vygotsky's who is credited with expanding the conception of mediation to include activity and not just individual action.

nodes.label: Danish, Enyedy, Saleh & Lee (2016)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Danish, J. A., Enyedy, N., Saleh, A., & Lee, C. (2016). Designing for Activity. In V. Svihla & R. Reeve (Eds.), Design as Scholarship: Case Studies from the Learning Sciences (pp. 26): Routledge.

nodes.label: Gutierréz & Jurow (2016)
nodes.notes:
**Citation**: Gutiérrez, K. D., & Jurow, A. S. (2016). Social Design Experiments: Toward Equity by Design. Journal of the Learning Sciences, 25(4), 565-598. doi: 10.1080/10508406.2016.1204548

"How can researchers organize design interventions that intentionally lever- age the diverse forms of expertise of nondominant communities so as to create the possibility of more consequential learning opportunities for them?" (p 4)

nodes.label: Baldwin, Mankoff, Nardi & Hayes (2020)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Baldwin, M. S., Mankoff, J., Nardi, B., & Hayes, G. (2020). An Activity Centered Approach to Nonvisual Computer Interaction. ACM Transactions on Computer-Human Interaction, 27(2), 1-27. doi:10.1145/3374211

nodes.label: Historical Actors
nodes.notes: Gutiérrez and Jurow (2016) note: "In other words, a desired outcome of these interventions is the development of conscious, meaning more intentional, **historical actors** (Espinoza, 2003) who can become designers of their own futures (Gutiérrez, 2008). Here the transformational process of becoming a historical actor involves developing a sense of one’s own identity in the broad context of time, including how particular cultural practices came into being and how they have enabled and constrained possibilities for learning, and how these understandings inform future-oriented practices. The coordination of past, present, and future-oriented actions and identities sets the conditions for new forms of agency central to realizing possible futures." p 3-4

nodes.label: Martínez-Álvarez (2019)
nodes.info: W15, Expansive learning, science learning, bilingual students, teacher candidates
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Martínez-Álvarez, P. (2019). What counts as science? Expansive learning actions for teaching and learning science with bilingual children. Cultural Studies of Science Education, 14(4), 799-837. doi:10.1007/s11422-019-09909-y

nodes.label: Carvalho et al (2015)
nodes.notes:
**Citation:** Carvalho, M. B., Bellotti, F., Berta, R., De Gloria, A., Sedano, C. I., Hauge, J. B., ... & Rauterberg, M. (2015). An activity theory-based model for serious games analysis and conceptual design. Computers & education, 87, 166-181.

Develops a model for understanding educational games using modified AT 'triangles'.

nodes.label: Vossoughi (2020)
nodes.info: W15, Embodiment, Maker spaces, elementary school children, ethical learning
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Vossoughi, S., Jackson, A., Chen, S., Roldan, W., & Escudé, M. (2020). Embodied pathways and ethical trails: Studying learning in and through relational histories. Journal of the Learning Sciences, 29(2), 183–223. https://doi.org/10.1080/10508406.2019.1693380

nodes.label: Wieselmann et al. (2020)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Wieselmann, J. R., Keratithamkul, K., Dare, E. A., Ring-Whalen, E. A., & Roehrig, G. H. (2020). Discourse Analysis in integrated STEM activities: Methods for examining power and positioning in small group interactions. Research in Science Education, 1-21.

nodes.label: Burnard (2007)
nodes.notes: **Citation:** Burnard, P. (2007). Reframing creativity and technology: Promoting pedagogic change in music education. Journal of Music, Technology and Education, 1(1), 37-55.

nodes.label: Canary & Cantu (2012)
nodes.notes: using mediation to understand parent-professional decision making regarding children with disabilities

nodes.label: Nogueira (2014)
nodes.notes:
**Citation**: Nogueira, A. L. H. (2014). Emotional experience, meaning, and sense production: Interweaving concepts to dialogue with the funds of identity approach. Culture & Psychology, 20(1), 49-58.

This paper aimed to situate semiotic mediation and emotional experience, as interwoven concepts inhent to the construction and appropriation of students' Funds of Identity.

nodes.label: Chizhik & Chizhik (2018)
nodes.info: W15, teacher preparation, mediation, lesson planning
nodes.notes:
**Citation**: Chizhik, E. W., & Chizhik, A. W. (2018). Using activity theory to examine how teachers' lesson plans meet students' learning needs. The Teacher Educator, 53(1), 67-85.
Attempt to understand how the lesson planning process mediate preservice teachers' learning about how their lesson plan impact students learning.

nodes.label: structurating activity theory (SAT)
nodes.notes:
SAT constructs of structuration through mediated activity, structural and system contradictions, and system intersections are useful for examining how ongoing mediated activity occurs and how the use of particular system elements, as rules and resources, reproduces or transforms structural features(Canary, 2010a).

"SAT integrates broad social action constructs from structuration theory (Giddens, 1984) with system-specific constructs from cultural-historical activity theory (Engestro ̈m, 1999). This combination helps explain how individuals from intersecting social systems, such as families and schools, construct meaning that is influenced by, and influences, system elements and broader social structures (Canary, 2010a)."

nodes.label: Goncu et al. (1999)
nodes.notes:
Goncu, A., Tuermer, U., Jain, J., & Johnson, D (1999). Children's play as cultural activity. In A. Goncu, S. Gaskins, Play and Development: 
Evolutionary, Sociocultural, and Functional Perspectives. Routledge, New York.

nodes.label: Witte & Haas (2005)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Witte, S. P., & Haas, C. (2005). Research in Activity: An Analysis of Speed Bumps as Mediational Means. Written Communication, 22(2), 127-165. doi:10.1177/0741088305274781

nodes.label: Engeström (2008)
nodes.notes: **Citation**: Engestrom, Y. (2008). The future of activity theory: A rough draft. University of Helsinki. In Keynote Lecture Provided at the ISCAR Conference (pp. 8-13).

nodes.label: Rogoff (Guided participation)
nodes.notes: Guided participation!

edges.notes: Need to elaborate.
Vygotsky sets out his notion of Play as tied to development here.
Vygotsky here lays out his definition of learning and its relationship to development.
This is the initial definition of the ZPD in our readings.
Identity is intertwined in this analysis
Jurow et al., use the notion of infrastructure to explore how values and practices in systems impact all of the participants / participation.
Vygotsky (1978) says that this is where the "best" learning happens.
At least one particular notion and how it relates to learning....
There are multiple forms of mediators, but tools and signs are key early forms discussed by Vygotsky (1978).
There are multiple forms of mediators, but tools and signs are key early forms discussed by Vygotsky (1978).
See Chaiklin's discussion of the Objective ZPD for details.
Gutiérrez (2002) notes how culture is constituted in activity systems so I linked them.
Technically, he cites a book chapter with similar ideas, but I wanted to show the awareness / link here.
Technically other pub, but I wanted to show the link.
(1991, but wanted to show the connection)
They've written a lot together so I wanted to make sure that was represented even though I didn't include one of those papers (yet).
Third space: connect out-of-school knowledge to school knowledge
analyzed contradictions
mentioned

Draws on ideas of appropriation "Whereas a person may first encounter an embodied movement as an example of a way of being and relating in the space, they may later sense the need to make use of these movements as resources for opening up particular kinds of experience with and for others"
Nogueira, A. L. H. (2014). Emotional experience, meaning, and sense production: Interweaving concepts to dialogue with the funds of identity approach. Culture & Psychology, 20(1), 49-58.
Activity theory is a part of the theoretical framework in this article. And, authors use activity theory as an analysis lens.

Embodied movements are co-constructed, and sensitive to the responses of participants in the moment, All of these instances required ethical calibration, both as a means to help others in ways that would be received, and as a way to sustain joint activity.

Similarly to Yamagata's piece, Wieselmann et al. (2020) also used activity theory to analyze phenomenon. Specifically, an introduce of new object may serve as a "disturbance" to expand and transform system.
Semiotic system is a part of the theoretical framework. Authors used multimodal analysis for interactions within a small groups. Here, multimode include verbal and non-verbal language.
an introduce of new object can expand what is possible within the activity system.
semiotic signs that are shaped by cultural, historical, and social context can mediate action
